block.p: Companies

Chrysler posted a $202 million profit for its third quarter, more than reversing its loss in the 1991 period. The auto maker could be the only one of the Big Three to avoid a quarterly loss. [ Page D1. ]
Citicorp reported a $116 million profit, in contrast to a loss a year earlier. Chemical posted a 35 percent gain in its net income, while Wells Fargo saw its earnings decline. [ D1. ]
Companies

Chrysler posted a $202 million profit for its third quarter, more than reversing its loss in the 1991 period. The auto maker could be the only one of the Big Three to avoid a quarterly loss. [ Page D1. ]
Citicorp reported a $116 million profit, in contrast to a loss a year earlier. Chemical posted a 35 percent gain in its net income, while Wells Fargo saw its earnings decline. [ D1. ]
Orders for the MD-11 wide-body jet have slowed so much that McDonnell Douglas is planning to cut production at least 40 percent in 1994, subcontractors and analysts say. [ D4. ]
Chambers Development said the S.E.C. is investigating after the concern said it mistakenly posted profit for three years. [ D4. ]
Compaq Computer reported a $49.4 million profit, turning around from a loss in the 1991 quarter. [ D4. ]
Humana posted a $166 million loss, partly as a result of charges related to the health-care concern's recent restructuring. [ D4. ]
Barbie will no longer say "math class is tough," since Mattel has responded to criticism from a women's group. [ D4. ]
I.B.M. introduced its line of low-cost personal computers. [ D5. ]
BellSouth's third-quarter net income dropped 2 percent, to $344.9 million, or 70 cents a share. [ D5. ]
Eli Lilly reported a third-quarter loss, but several other drug and health-care companies posted higher earnings. [ D5. ]
Whirlpool named a new president and chief operating officer in a move to help the appliance maker's overseas expansion. [ D5. ]
Washington Post reported a 9.1 percent gain in its earnings, while Tribune reported a 2 percent drop. [ D17. ] The Economy
Builders started new construction in September at an annual rate that was 1.4 percent faster than in the preceding month. [ D2. ]
There is no question that U.S. airlines and banks are struggling, but Ross Perot may have overstated the problems in the Presidential debates. News analysis. [ D6. ]
Advocates say higher gasoline mileage rules would create jobs in the auto industry, contradicting President Bush. [ D6. ]
A Federal judge denied public access to information at a criminal plea hearing in an insider-trading case. [ D6. ] International
The Bundesbank signaled that it was cautiously guiding Germany's money-market rates lower, raising hopes that the German central bank might cut its key interest rates. [ D2. ] Markets
Bond prices fell sharply in the Treasury market, but an $844 million bond issue was sold by New York City at the second lowest cost in 20 years. [ D1. ]
The stock market was mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average slipping 2.43 points, to 3,186.02. [ D8. ]

Coffee futures prices surged as Brazilian producers continued to withhold their crop from the market. [ D16. ] The dollar rose against most foreign currencies. Gold prices also rose. [ D16. ] Business Technology
Advances in the design of oil-drilling platforms enabled hundreds of offshore rigs to stand up to Hurricane Andrew's fury. [ D1. ]
A new system can confirm the identities of credit card holders, based on the measurements of their hands. [ D7. ] Today's Columns
Home Shopping Network is getting another look from analysts since new Federal regulations were imposed on the cable television industry. Market Place. [ D8. ]
Frito-Lay will sponsor the halftime show at Super Bowl XXVII. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D17. ]
